chapter.title: Introduction
chapter.para: The Telepathy framework allows applications to use real-time communications via several common protocols, such as XMPP (Jabber). For instance, an instant messenger application might use Telepathy to allow chats with online contacts via accounts with various IM services. Or a game might use Telepathy to simplify the implementation of its networking code, allowing users to play against each other.
Telepathy is a D-Bus API so it may be used from most programming languages.
All this functionality is available under an open source license, allowing people to make improvements and add new features.

chapter.title: Installation
chapter.para: If you are using a common Linux distribution you may already have the Telepathy packages installed. For instance, it is a dependency of the Empathy instant messenging client. However, you will probably still need some extra packages to build the examples in this book.

sect1.title: Installation on Ubuntu Linux
sect1.para: You can install the Telepathy packages from the command line Terminal with this command: sudo apt-get install telepathy-devel libtelepathy-glib-dev

sect1.title: Installation on Fedora Linux
sect1.para: You can install the Telepathy packages from the command line Terminal with this command, as root: yum install telepathy-glib-devel telepathy-gabble telepathty-butterfly telepathy-haze telepathy-salut telepathy-stream-engine

chapter.title: Basics
chapter.para: This chapter introduces some basic techniques and concepts that you must understand to use Telepathy confidently. You should read through this chapter before proceeding, but you will probably want to refer back here again later.

sect1.title: Using D-Bus
sect1.para: Telepathy is a D-BusD-Bus API. Telepathy components conform to the Telepathy D-Bus Specification, which is therefore also the main Telepathy API reference.

D-Bus is an IPCIPC (Inter-process communication) system, allowing different software components to be implemented in different processes, with different programming languages. It also allows multiple applications to easily share functionality from a single process. Most examples in this book will use language bindings instead of using D-Bus directly. However, an understanding of the following D-Bus concepts will help you even when using language bindings.

listitem.para: A process can make a service available by connecting to a D-Bus bus and requesting a "well-known" bus name for the connection, such as "com.mycompany.TextEditor", by which other processes, such as applications, can access it.
The service process provides D-Bus objects on that bus name. Each object has an object path, such as "/com/company/TextEditor", which a client application must specify to use that object.

Each D-Bus object implements one or more D-Bus interface. Each interface has an interface name, such as "com.mycompany.TextEditor". Each interface provides one or more method or signal, each with a member name.

sect1.para: Of course, for simple services with just one object that provides just one interface, these three names will often look very similar.

In the following sections you will see how a D-Bus API can be used from some common programming languages. Remember that these examples only create proxies to the D-Bus objects, providing a way to use their API. The actual objects are instantiated in the service's process.

In these examples, we use the FreeDesktop Notification system, which should be available on most modern Linux installations. The examples should cause a message to popup from your desktop panel. Note that, like Telepathy, this service is available on the Session BusSession Bus rather than the System BusSystem Bus. Services on the Session Bus are for the current user's session only. Services on the System Bus are shared between all users.

These programming languages allow you to call D-Bus methods synchronously, meaning that they block until they can return the method's result. However, that is generally disapproved of because the D-Bus service may take a long time to reply, and because of some fundamental technical problems with the use of blocking calls between processes. Therefore, the examples call the D-Bus method asynchronously, theoretically allowing the application to continue with other tasks while waiting for the result.

sect2.title: Using D-Bus from C, with glib

sect3.title: Calling Methods
sect3.para: This example uses dbus-glib's dbus_g_proxy_begin_call() function to call the Notify() method on the org.freedesktop.Notification interface of the desktop notification service at the /org/freedesktop/Notification path. Note that we must specify the types of each parameter. The specified callback function then calls dbus_g_proxy_end_call() to retreive the result.
We could have used the synchronous dbus_g_proxy_call() function instead but, as already mentioned, asynchronous calls are generally preferred with D-Bus.

sect3.title: Using Properties
sect3.para: D-Bus properties are available via an additional org.freedesktop.DBus.Properties interface on some objects, which provides Get(), Set() and GetAll methods. You can call these methods to get or set property values for the object's other interfaces.

As of this writing, telepathy-glib has no simple API for dealing with properties so you must call these functions directly. Therefore this example is therefore very similar to the Calling Methods example.

sect3.title: Handling Signals
sect3.para: D-Bus signal handlers may be specified with dbus-glib with the dbus_g_proxy_connect_signal() function. As when calling D-Bus methods, you must specify the expected types, but for signals you must do this in a previous call to dbus_g_proxy_add_signal(). The specified callback function will then be called when the signal is emitted. This example connects to the "DeviceAdded" signal of the "org.freedesktop.Hal.Manager" interface so it can print a message to the terminal when, for instance, you plug in a USB stick.

This example connects to the "DeviceAdded" signal of the "org.freedesktop.Hal.Manager" interface so it can print a message to the terminal when, for instance, you plug in a USB stick.

sect1.title: Language Bindings
sect1.para: As mentioned in the Using D-Bus section, many programming languages have their own generic ways of using D-Bus APIs. In addition, there are some Telepathy-specific APIs to make the use of Telepathy even easier. For instance, telepathy-glib provides an API that is familiar to users of Glib and GTK+, using the GObject system and related conventions.
Likewise, the Telepathy-Qt project provides a more Qt-like API for Telepathy and Telepathy-Python does the same for Python.

Remember that, like raw use of D-Bus from these programming languages, the Telepathy language bindings only create proxies to the D-Bus objects, providing a way to use their API. The actual objects are instantiated in the service's process.

sect2.title: telepathy-glib
sect2.para: The C examples in this book will use telepathy-glib, which provides a GObject-based API for the Telepathy framework.

sect3.title: Asynchronous Calls
sect3.para: For each Telepathy D-Bus method, telepathy-glib generally provides both a "run" and a "call" function. For instance, tp_cli_connection_run_connect() and tp_cli_connection_call_connect(). The "run" function is synchronous, blocking until the D-Bus service has returned the value, whereas the "call" function is asynchronous, immediately returning and later providing the result to a callback function.

However, the Telepathy developers strongly discourage the use of the "run" functions, so all examples in this book will use the asynchronous "call" functions. This complicates application code but it is more robust and allows the application to be more responsive, doing more than one thing at a time.

sect3.title: Generated Functions
sect3.para: telepathy-glib provides both hand-coded and generated API. The generated functions have these prefixes:

listitem.para: These functions are useful for client applications. For instance, tp_cli_connection_run_connect().
These functions are useful for service implementations, such as connection managers. For instance, tp_svc_connection_implement_connect().

sect3.para: The generated functions make simple direct calls to the D-Bus methods, without any additional logic and without using more appropriate types. For instance, they use unsigned integers for parameters because D-Bus does not have a concept of enumerations. However, the Telepathy D-Bus Specification does describe enumerations of possible values for these parameters, so the hand-written functions do use enums. Likewise, raw D-Bus methods can only identify object instances in terms of a bus name and object path combination, but telepathy-glib can directly provide a GObject instance that is a proxy for a D-Bus object without exposing those intermediate details.

Hand-coded functions have a simple tp_ prefix and should be preferred whenever they exist. The generated functions exist only because hand-written functions have not yet been implemented for all Telepathy D-Bus methods.
In addition to more pleasant syntax, some hand-written objects contain a large amount of useful logic which can simplify application code. For instance, TpContact uses GObject signals.

sect3.title: Instantiation and Readiness
sect3.para: Some of the hand-coded objects, such as TpConnection and TpChannel, call additional D-Bus methods to acquire necessary information. When they have received this information they are then "ready", meaning that other hand-written functions can then be called. This concept of "readiness" does not exist in the raw D-Bus API because it describes the status of the hand-written behaviour. For instance, you should call tp_connection_call_when_ready() after instantiating a TpConnection, or tp_channel_call_when_ready() after instantiating a TpChannel.

sect1.title: Connection Managers
sect1.para: Support for the various communication protocols is provided by several Connection Managers. For instance, the telepathy-gabble Connection Manager provides support for the XMPP protocol, also known as Jabber.

There is no central &app; D-Bus service. Instead there are several connection manager services, activated on demand, and each of these connection managers provide the same core set of D-Bus interfaces, such as Connection and Channel, allowing application code to be written generically for all connection managers.

sect1.title: Optional Interfaces
sect1.para: Although a core set of D-Bus interfaces is provided by all connection managers, some extra D-Bus interfaces are optional. For instance, some connection managers only provide extra interfaces when they discover that the remote server provides that optional functionality. Therefore, when using these interfaces, application code should first check that the interface is available, sometimes falling back to alternative interfaces.

For instance, use the Connection interface's GetInterfaces() method. For ConnectionManagers and Channels use their Interfaces D-Bus property. Eventually Connection will also have an Interfaces property, when its GetInterfaces() method will be deprecated.
When using telepathy-glib, you can simply call the tp_proxy_has_interface() function for TpConnectionManager, TpConnection, or TpChannel.
Actually, the core interfaces are only "recommended" by the Telepathy D-Bus specification so you should check before using any interface even if it is not commonly considered to be optional.

note.para: Note that the Interfaces property (or the Connection.GetInterfaces() method) does more than the standard D-Bus Introspectable.Introspect() method. The Telepathy-specific mechanism allows tools and language bindings to know about the possible availability of interfaces via Introspect() while providing an additional check that the interface is really supported for the particular connection manager with the particular remote server to which that connection manager is connected.

sect1.title: Handles
sect1.para: The Telepathy D-Bus API does not have D-Bus objects to represent contacts, groups, or rooms. These are instead identified by numeric handles. This is for performance reasons, and because it is easier to compare numeric handles than to discover if two D-Bus proxy objects refer to the same object instance.

These numeric handles are only unique within a Telepathy Connection. For instance, don't try to use a Connection's contact handle with a different Connection. The handles also only make sense when combined with a handle type, telling the API whether it represents a contact, group, or list. In fact, two handles may be numerically identical but be for different types.

sect2.title: Hold and Release
sect2.para: When a Telepathy object has finished with a handle that number may be forgotten and even reused later as a handle for a completely different item. However, your application may wish to "hold" the handle for a longer time. To do so, you should call the Connection's HoldHandles() method and call ReleaseHandles() when you have finished with the handle. However, a single ReleaseHandles() call will release a handle regardless of how many times HoldHandles() has been called, so be careful not to call it while other code may be using the handle.

This is less necessary when using Telepathy language bindings, such as telepathy-glib, because they may automatically hold and release handles for the lifetime of their objects, such as telepathy-glib's TpContact object. Additionally, telepathy-glib wraps the HoldHandles() and ReleaseHandles() D-Bus methods with the tp_connection_hold_handles() and tp_connection_unref_handles() functions which reference-count the client-side handle "hold", allowing you to match each tp_connection_hold_handles() call with a call to tp_connection_release_handles().
In the later sections we will mention when it actually makes sense to do this when using specific parts of the Telapathy API.

sect1.title: API conventions
sect1.para: Telepathy's method names follow a simple convention.

listitem.simpara: Methods prefixed with Request are aysnchronous, meaning that the result will be provided later and your application should not block while it waits. For instance, Connection.RequestChannel().

Methods prefixed with Get are synchronous, meaning that the result will be returned immediately. These methods generally access local information and do not need to make any contact with the remote server. For instance, Connection.GetStatus().

sect1.para: See the Using D-Bus section to learn more about asynchronous D-Bus method calls. Note that many Get methods may be replaced with D-Bus properties in future, which will also be syncronous.
See also the telepathy-glib section about its function naming conventions.

chapter.title: Connection Manager
chapter.para: As mentioned in the Basics chapter, each ConnectionManager provides support for a communication protocol.

All Telepathy Connection Managers have bus names that begin with "org.freedesktop.Telepathy.ConnectionManager" so you can discover all available connection managers by calling the D-Bus ListActivatableNames() method and then comparing the names with that prefix. telepathy-glib provides the tp_list_connection_managers() function that conveniently does this.

You may then discover what protocols are provided by each connection manager by calling the ConnectionManagers's ListProtocols() D-Bus method. telepathy-glib's TpConnectionManager object calls this automatically and emits the got-info signal when it has returned. You can examine the TpConnectionManager::protocols struct field in your signal handler.

Applications, such as IM clients, might choose to offer the user a choice from that list of protocols and then use the appropriate connection manager. Others might use only one protocol and therefore hard-code the connection manager's bus name.

sect1.title: Connecting
sect1.para: To attempt a connection to the remote server, for instance to your Jabber IM account, call a ConnectionManager's RequestConnection() D-Bus method, providing the connection details. If the connection succeeds then this method returns the bus name and object path of a Telepathy Connection object.

As of this writing, there is no hand-coded telepathy-glib function to request the connection and directly provide a TpConnection proxy. However, you may use the generated tp_cli_connection_manager_call_request_connection() function. In the callback, you can then use the provided bus name and object path to instantiate a TpConnection proxy object.

sect1.title: Presence
sect1.para: If a protocol has a concept of presence, showing when users are online or available, then that ConnectionManager's Connection will provide the SimplePresence interface. This interface has functions to set and get the current presence for the connected account. It also has a PresencesChanged signal to detect changes to the presence caused by other clients.
